The artists you look up to have years of practice and layers of understanding of the creative process.

They went through the same process (and feelings!) you're experiencing, but their perseverance was worth it.

And it's worth it for you.

It's so easy to fall into the trap of seeing beautiful art, trying to recreate it, and getting discouraged that you can't quite grasp it. 

This discouragement leads to feelings of "I must be a bad artist" or "If I can't do that, why should I bother?"

This one is so important it deserves its own tweet:

3. Draw at YOUR level, not where you think you should be.

Over time, you will build your capacity for the challenge. Your understanding will also grow, and you can handle more.

If you're unsure where to start, working with a mentor or following guides like DrawABox can be very helpful for the "what should I study" question.

2. Study in small, manageable bursts. 

You don't need hours upon hours of practice in a day to make progress, and it's especially counterintuitive if that practice is so frustrating that you avoid drawing for a week.

Study once a day in 15-30 minute intervals in the beginning.

1. A strong sense of why drawing is important to you is a powerful motivator. 

This will push you through difficult practice sessions, bad drawings, and countless hours of asking, "Why isn't this working?"

You will get there. Your reason to draw will keep you going.

The key to showing up involves 3 things:
1. Knowing WHY you want to draw.

2. Limiting the frustration per session based on your capacity for it to avoid burnout.

3. Aim to create art at your level, not where you think you should be.

If you've ever tried to draw, you know how hard it is!

You also know how frustrating it can be to envision something in your head that turns out like a 2nd grader drew it on paper.

When things are difficult, it is human nature to avoid it. It's a survival thing. Even though drawing is difficult in a nonsurvival way, our brain similarly registers all fear and pain.

Let's talk about how to work through it.

There are countless nuances about how to get good at drawing, but most people struggle with the number one step:

Showing up to draw.

That's a very discouraging feeling!

I relate to that a lot. I had to reframe the way I looked at studying in general--it became more about curiosity than a task to check off. 

It helps suck you in a little more organically into what you're drawing. Make discoveries, not grind!

I think this is super relatable. But creating something you can reference would be really helpful!

Even if it's just some notes you take along the way c:

It does make sense!

If you like a lot of different styles, it might help to make a list of all the individual things you like about each. From that, what if you made your own style based on your likes instead of trying to pick just one?

Baby steps!! It can be really hard not to compare where you're starting again to where you once were.

Be kind to yourself <3

Maybe taking down some notes in those motivated moments of your thoughts, how intense the feeling are, and what triggered them--might give you more clues!

If it happens, it means we can recreate it!
I see! What usually motivates you?
What if you just flipped a coin or threw a bunch of things into a RNG?

Consuming too much art and drawing too little can often lead to this.

Art is inspiring, but if you’re getting the opposite effect, it might be time to take a break from scrolling and draw instead.

Backgrounds are HARD, and let's be honest - most of us want to focus on the figure. 

But backgrounds help tell the story of our characters, and they shouldn't be neglected. That doesn't mean we have to start by drawing huge, hyper-detailed scenes for our characters from scratch.

Hobbyists use art reference.
Newbies use art reference.
Teachers use art reference. 
Everyone uses reference.

Use reference for your art.
You're not cheating.

Start drawing today. 

Either a year passes and you still haven't drawn, or a year passes and you have a whole year of drawing practice under your belt.

Backgrounds are HARD, and let's be honest - most of us want to focus on the figure. 

But backgrounds help tell the story of our characters, and they shouldn't be neglected. That doesn't mean we have to start by drawing huge, hyper-detailed scenes for our characters from scratch.

Most artists miss a day of drawing and then try to motivate themselves with shame and guilt.

"You're not a real artist. A real artist would be drawing right now."

This never serves your creativity—it only hurts your self-confidence.

Encourage yourself like you would a friend.

Telling yourself “I only have 30 minutes to draw, it’s not worth it” adds up to weeks of zero progress.

Here's your sign to start.

Most artists miss a day of drawing and then try to motivate themselves with shame and guilt.

"You're not a real artist. A real artist would be drawing right now."

This never serves your creativity—it only hurts your self-confidence.

Encourage yourself like you would a friend.

Try not to forget:

We begin drawing because of our childlike curiosity to replicate - to understand, to dissect - what interests us. The desire to be "good" was never why you picked up the pencil in the first place.

Experiment. Be a kid again.
Let every sketch be a stepping stone, not a final product. Lower your expectations to make showing up easier.

Things to remember if you're a tired artist:
- Quit the doomscroll
- Prep before you sit down
- Embrace small wins
- Bad sketches are good practice
- Draw before your brain talks you out of it
- Rest when you need it.

Try not to forget:

We begin drawing because of our childlike curiosity to replicate - to understand, to dissect - what interests us. The desire to be "good" was never why you picked up the pencil in the first place.

Experiment. Be a kid again.

Stop worrying about wasting time drawing "the wrong thing."

Every drawing is practice.

📌 Ways to make money with your art in 2025 without relying on freelance or studio work:

If you're an artist who juggles a day job, a social life, and trying to keep up a regular sleep schedule while eating and treating your body well, you know how hard it is to find the time and energy for your art.

Don’t let doomscrolling steal that time.

Stop worrying about wasting time drawing "the wrong thing."

Every drawing is practice.

Easy art hack to get the most out of your drawing session:

Prepare and gather your reference material the night before drawing. Then, wake up early and start drawing before you do anything else. You'll start with full energy, focus, and motivation.

Art advice you can use right now:

Draw slower
Observe more
Observe again
Don’t give up after the first sketch
Use references 
Ask for feedback
Work simple, then add details
Iterate on ideas
Try a new process
Make frequent comparisons to refs
Draw what you love
Draw with others

"I don't have enough time to draw."

This thought is sabotaging your progress. 

30 minutes daily can lead to results, but you must take the chance.

If you're scrolling for "inspiration," I've got bad news. 

The continuous cycle of dopamine hits released when scrolling through an endless entertainment feed destroys your motivation and makes it hard to focus.

If you get frustrated when drawing, scrolling won't make things easier.

You must believe in your artistic vision.

If you don't, who will?

If your audience saw your "twist" coming or guess what's gonna happen, there's a 95% chance that's a good thing. It means you foreshadowed and your characters are consistent enough to predict. Good job! +1 Writer Point for you!

Hey peeps! If you’re enjoying the content I put out I want to give a quick heads up:

If you want to help me to grow then reposting my posts is the easiest way to do so. 

Bluesky doesn’t have an algorithm like Twitter that works with likes. The best way to show up on users feeds is if you repost! 🫂

artists 🎨

Bluesky tip for newbies: Bluesky has no real algorithm. Likes here do nothing but show the poster that you enjoyed their content.

That kindness is always going to be appreciated by creators, but if you want to help to boost something here, you have to repost it so others see it. 🙂

When you’re working through a creative challenge, and your frustration is beginning to lead you to self-doubt, know this:

Easy art hack to get the most out of your drawing session:

Prepare and gather your reference material the night before drawing. Then, wake up early and start drawing before you do anything else. You'll start with full energy, focus, and motivation.

Consider the power of drawing daily for 30 minutes:

- 30 minutes of drawing a day = 15 hours a month
- 15 hours of drawing a month = 1 full illustration
- 1 full illustration monthly = 12 illustrations a year

Your portfolio is going to start filling up pretty quickly.

Another day, another million new people have joined Bluesky! 

18M users? 🙂‍↔️ 18M friends 🙂‍↕️

Seeing a student graduate from my mentorship after a year is truly beautiful. 

I can't explain how I feel to hear that someone can rekindle the joy in their relationship with art, learn to trust their intuition, and practice self-kindness when creating.

I just have a big, proud smile on my face.

The great thing is, while some might see this mindset leading to losing followers, the amount of joy and effort you put into work will lead to MORE growth.

Seems paradoxical, but true. Draw for yourself first. ✌️

Every time you scroll, your brain gets a dopamine hit. It feels good, it's mindless—it numbs your anxiety.  

Here's the catch: it messes with your motivation and focus, making the creation process impossible.  

If you struggle to focus while drawing, drop social media for a week.

your friend at month 1 of their newest game dev role: this studio is so chill and everyone is so nice. no drama here!!!

You are far more powerful than you believe.

Avoid scrolling during droughts of inspiration or moments of low motivation. Social media will drain your dopamine—and we need dopamine to feel motivated!

Instead, try:
- walking in nature
- exercise or yoga
- automatic drawing/writing
- sitting in the sun

Creative growth doesn’t happen in comfort zones, but sustainability requires periodic comfort.

Know when to push. 
Know when to rest.

Never neglect one for the other.

awwabbbwb ⭐ The advice is spot-on (a warning about balance and being wary of bad habits ♥)

I feel like this quiz will be extra helpful for folks starting out (either the business side or simply to bring more consistency in their art practice in the long-term) and/or struggling with motivation.

If you regularly rest from drawing, you won't need to fight burnout for 6 months to compensate for it.

Listen to your body and your mind.
